item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description: What would the SQL query look like for get_user_by() ? I don't know enough about SQL to derive it from the query in get_term_by().

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description:
When I tried $userdata->has_cap('publish_posts'), I got "Fatal error: Call to undefined method stdClass::has_cap()". I was hoping I could check the capabilities directly from $userdata (it's in there!).

Are you sure you want get_user_by()? When specifying email and login, for example, there are different sanitize functions that need to be called from within the function.

item.title: Ticket #4913 (Future posts cause term count to increase) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Here's an untested patch. It should update counts for all of the post's terms when the post is published.

item.title: 4913.diff attached to Ticket #4913
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Update term counts when future post is published

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
WP_User is the way to go. What was the error, exactly.

Also, instead of adding another get_userdata* function, let's add get_user_by(). 

function get_user_by($field, $value, $output = OBJECT, $filter = 'raw')
get_user_by('email', 'blah@blah.blah');

get_term_by() offers an example.

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description: Revised patch to call new function in pluggable.php. Is there a way to check the capabilities directly from userdata without doing a "new WP_User"? I got an undefined method when I tried that.

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Replying to Bobcat:

OK, I can pattern it after get_userdatabylogin, but I don't know what to do with the following code: 

$user_id = wp_cache_get($user_login, 'userlogins');
$userdata = wp_cache_get($user_id, 'users');
if ( $userdata )
        return $userdata;

Is there an equivalent for user_email? If so, how do I use it?

There is no equivalent at the moment - for now code it without the caching and we can decide what to cache it on afterwards.

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description:
OK, I can pattern it after get_userdatabylogin, but I don't know what to do with the following code: 

$user_id = wp_cache_get($user_login, 'userlogins');
$userdata = wp_cache_get($user_id, 'users');
if ( $userdata )
        return $userdata;

Is there an equivalent for user_email? If so, how do I use it?

item.title: Ticket #2284 (Extra Hooks in the Edit Page Table) updated
item.dc:creator: scompt
item.description:
I've just released a plugin which provides the 'manage_pages_columns' and 'manage_pages_custom_column' hooks. It hooks onto the wp action and records the extra column information which is then added into the dom using jQuery after the page is finished loading.

You can check it out at ​http://scompt.com/projects/manage-pages-custom-columns-in-wordpress

item.title:
Ticket #5241 (Embedding Stage6 Video Inserts
tag and breaks all themes.) closed
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
worksforme:

This code works fine for me: 

<object><param name="foo" value="bar" /></object>

It ends up as this: 

<p><object>
<param name="foo" value="bar" /></object></p>

Remove all line breaks from your code, i.e. don't have this: 

<object>
<param name="foo" value="bar" />
</object>

because that would add in <br /> as intended (you have a line break there, so you must "want" a <br />.

Also make sure to not use the RTE editor (i.e. paste into the "Code" tab or disable it altogether).

item.title:
Ticket #5241 (Embedding Stage6 Video Inserts
tag and breaks all themes.) created
item.dc:creator: Manthem86
item.description:
Embedding of DiVX Stage6 videos at ​http://stage6.divx.com/videos/ using the DiVX web embed tool at ​http://labs.divx.com/WebPlayerCodeGenerator inserts a <br> tag which causes the theme to break. I've tested this on multiple themes and they all had the same result.

Below is what the code should look like, followed by the outputted code from WP. 

Desired Code:
<object codebase="http://" height="576" width="720" classid="clsid:67DABFBF-D0AB-41fa-9C46-CC0F21721616"><param name="autoplay" value="false">
Actual Code:
<object codebase="http://" height="544" width="960" classid="clsid:67DABFBF-D0AB-41fa-9C46-CC0F21721616"><BR/><param name="autoplay" value="false">

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated

Good Patch.

I think we should consider creating a get_userbyemail function and adding it to wp-includes/pluggable.php rather than continuing with the embedded query in wp-mail.php.

item.title: Ticket #4642 (Enhanced wp-mail.php) updated
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description:
Keywords changed

Added patch 4642.2.diff, which sets the post_status based on the author's capabilities. (Email address validation removed as requested.) Tested with WP 2.3 + #5169 by sending test emails from users with and without publish_posts capability, and also from an unknown user.

item.title: 4642.2.diff attached to Ticket #4642
item.dc:creator: Bobcat
item.description: wp-mail.php patch to set post_status based on the author's capabilities

item.title: Ticket #5240 (taxonomy - incorrect query in update or insert term to increase term_group) created
item.dc:creator: michelwp
item.description:
In both functions (wp_insert_term and wp_update_term, the SQL query - to increase the term_group when creating an alias of a term not yet in a term_group - is incorrect.

The query was 

SELECT MAX(term_group) FROM $wpdb->terms GROUP BY term_group

but must be 

SELECT MAX(term_group) FROM $wpdb->terms

GROUP BY is not here necessary !

(I am testing taxonomy.php script and features to create a multilingual dictionary of terms that can be used in themes or elsewhere)

About alias_of features : See also Trac #5230

item.title: Ticket #5233 (update.php documentation) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
I think that the documentation in the code should describe the purpose of the function and it's arguments and returns to enable it to be called.

Any extra information like how to disable a feature should not be in the documentation.

That kind of information is better stored in the codex.

item.title: Ticket #4478 (Allow login form to be completely taken over) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Replying to Otto42:

I don't see why Playstation's blog would have needed more than a custom plugin to do what they did. wp-login.php is littered with hooks, and their customizations appear to be using those hooks, near as I can tell.

Reference Ticket #3123

Yes, the "date of birth" is easy as cake due to #3123 but the sidebar, header, etc. aren't unless I'm missing something obvious.

item.title: Ticket #4478 (Allow login form to be completely taken over) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Possibly another method that could be used is a action before most of the wp-login.php code is run.

A plugin could hook the action and then die to prevent the main login page running. That can be done in the admin section already by hooking the load-page.php action, So maybe doing the same for the login form should be possible if its 'backend' and as such, not template styled.

item.title: Ticket #4478 (Allow login form to be completely taken over) updated
item.dc:creator: cpoteet
item.description: +1 for Richon's suggestion.

item.title: Ticket #5232 (Get the current action and current filter name) updated
item.dc:creator: darkdragon
item.description:
The static approach would have to work like the global one where after the action is take, it sets the current action to the old one. The reason for this is for hooks that call other hooks. You would lose the previous information.

So +1 for mdawaffe's solution, but only if it is combined with tellyworth's.

item.title: Ticket #5232 (Get the current action and current filter name) updated
item.dc:creator: tellyworth
item.description: Another approach that I tried but rejected for simplicity's sake was to use an array and pop/push, so it's possible to see the stack of actions when they are nested. That could be combined with mdawaffe's static approach.

item.title: Ticket #5205 (RSS2 Feed Enhancement) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Keywords changed

Replying to lexhair:

Replying to rubys:

wouldn't bloginfo('atom_url') also need fixing?

I looked at feed-atom.php and you are correct. As it is in the trunk, it will not return the correct self link for a category feed. That might be a separate, low level defect ticket since it exists rather than this ticket which is an enhancement to RSS2. JMHO.

Raised as #5238

item.title: Ticket #5238 (Self links in feeds are incorrect for categories) created
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Raised from #5205

We use bloginfo('atom_url') and bloginfo('rss_url') to build the self links but these return the links to the main atom and rss urls the underlying function called (get_feed_link) needs to be used instead and made category aware.

item.title: Ticket #5235 (Add Pre-flight checks to install) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
AFAIK WordPress still uses mail() by default unless a plugin is loaded to replace it.

One check which would be good is to check if mail() is disabled. 

if( null === @mail('','','') )

false will be raised if mail() is available, as the email is incorrect.
null will be raised if mail() is disabled.
